div.em: Current conditions as of 19 Apr 13:53 pm CDT

div.div: Partly sunny, with a high near 55. North northeast wind around 5 mph.

A chance of rain and thunderstorms before 3am, then a slight chance of showers between 3am and 4am. Mostly cloudy, with a low around 39. East northeast wind around 5 mph becoming west after midnight. Chance of precipitation is 40%.
Sunny, with a high near 66. Breezy, with a northwest wind 5 to 10 mph increasing to 15 to 20 mph in the afternoon. Winds could gust as high as 30 mph.

div.p: The Nebraska Family Helpline at (888) 866-8660 makes it easier for families to obtain assistance by providing a single contact point 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Trained Helpline operators screen calls to assess immediate safety needs, identify the potential level of a behavioral health crisis, make recommendations or referrals to appropriate resources, and help callers connect to emergency resources or providers. The Helpline is supervised by licensed mental health professionals.

This service is especially prepared to help families facing unique struggles due to the Covis-19 quarantine. If your family is experiencing troubles with sibling rivalry, changes in sleep habits, issues with completing homework or usual chores, or just a general feeling of unrest, please call this number and get help.

a.aria-label: Read more about Nebraska Family Helpline (888) 866-8660

span.style: font-family:"Segoe UI", "Segoe UI Web (West European)", "Segoe UI", -apple-system, system-ui, Roboto, "Helvetica Neue", sans-serif

span.span: Caretakers, Randy Sprick's YouTube video entitled "Positive and Productive Childcare While the Kids are Not in School" is very helpful in addressing parenting issues. Randy offers ten basic parenting rules.

span.span: Due to Health Dept. guidelines the Wheeler Central School Board will hold the Monday, April 13th Board Meeting at 7:00 p.m. by ZOOM link. The link can be opened by logging onto ZOOM at https://zoom.us/j/9202522471 . If you don’t have an account, you will first need to create one to connect to the Board meeting. Meeting agendas will be available in the High School Office.

div.p: The Board of Education of Chambers Public Schools will have a joint meeting with the board of Wheeler Central Public Schools at 7:00 pm on Tuesday, April 14, 2020, by videoconference due to current statewide restrictions related to COVID-19. Public and media access to the videoconference is available by clicking on the link that will be posted on the district’s website at www.chamberspublic.org. This link will take you to a live stream via ZOOM. All public comment at this meeting must be submitted in advance in writing to Superintendent Frank Jesse (frankjesse@esu8.org) or Superintendent Rod Olson (rodney.olson@wbroncs.org) and will be distributed to the Board of Education when received. There will be no live public comment to keep the meeting brief as recommended by the Nebraska Attorney General.

As this board meeting will be held by videoconference, and no quorum of the Board of Education will be physically present together, there will be no in-person attendance available to the public or the media. A copy of the agenda, kept continuously current, is available for public inspection upon request from Superintendent Frank Jesse (frankjesse@esu8.org or 402-482-5233) or from Superintendent Rod Olson (rodney.olson@wbrongcs.org or 308-654-3273.

a.aria-label: Read more about Notice of Meeting

h3.a: Assignment and Food Drop off Update

div.p: On Thursday April 9th, we will drop off one last folder for Elementary students at your home that will include assignments until the end of the year and ask that you place a tote or box outside your door with the previous week’s folder and library books that you are not using for class assignments yet. We are moving away from a common pickup site and more electronic communication due to heightened Covid-19 concerns at the State and National level. Please note that there may be additional assignments, but each teacher will reach out to you and get you the information electronically. We are going to try to include as much as we can in the final folder before it goes out. Then instead of bringing folders back in, we ask that you either text, e-mail, send through Facebook Messenger, FaceTime, or Seesaw App. You can scan them or take a picture and send into each teacher. The food drop-off will still continue on Fridays after this Thursday drop-off, so if you could continue to put your tote or box out your door on Friday; they will place it in there. If you have any questions, please contact the school or your child’s teacher.

Just a quick reminder that the Wheeler County Mobile Food Pantry is Tuesday April 7th. Boxes for pickup will be ready starting at 11:00 a.m. The pickup site has been moved to the cafeteria located next to the main gym in the Elementary. Due to the Covid-19 virus we ask that you either pull up to or park in front of the cafeteria so that boxes can be delivered to your car or truck.

a.aria-label: Read more about Assignment and Food Drop off Update

h3.a: Tips for Parents During COVID-19 Pandemic

div.p: Tips for Parents During COVID-19 Pandemic

li.p: Limit Media and Social Media Exposure – This is good advice for people of all ages. The target audience of media outlets is adults, so their broadcasts can cause even more confusion and anxiety for younger children.

Have a Routine – With school out it is important to establish a new daily routine. Wake up, get dressed, complete distance learning school work, eat meals, and go to bed at the same time each day. Create a schedule that includes these things plus relaxation time, chores, exercise, creative time, etc.
Allow Your Child to be in Closer Proximity to You – With so much change and uncertainty, children may need additional reassurance.
Make Time to Allow Your Child to Talk About How They are Feeling – Ask open ended questions, listen without interruption and avoid the temptation to quickly provide a solution to their concerns.

Provide Factual Reassurance AFTER They Have Had a Chance to Express How They are Feeling – Honesty and accuracy is critical. Facts to consider sharing:
● Most people do not have COVID-19 and most people who have it don’t get seriously ill
● We can control the spread of the disease by washing our hands and avoiding contact
● The nation’s best medical professionals are working to help people with COVID-19 some
of which are right here in Nebraska.
● If true, remind them that everyone in their family is fine.

Tell Your Children You Love Them and Spend More Time with Them – Make more time than usual to share activities together; play games, read to each other, watch a movie, create art, sing and dance, go for a walk outside.
Encourage Teens to Do Stress Reducing Activities – read, journal, write poetry or short stories, draw, exercise, listen to music, or simply close their eyes and focus on taking slow deep breaths.
As Much as Possible Have Your Child Eat Healthy Well-Balanced Meals – this has an impact on mental and physical health.
If You Have Concerns Reach Out to Your Child’s School Counselor – you may contact me at 308.215.8064 or derickson@wbroncs.org.

a.aria-label: Read more about Tips for Parents During COVID-19 Pandemic
